On Jan 9, 2008 9:23 AM, qmjasim <n2opower@...> wrote:
>
> I am Faisal's group mate in our final year project and we are trying
>  to integrate NEAT with RoboCup Soccer simulation.
>  What we wanted to know is whether NEAT learns in a situation where the
>  inputs are constantly changing and it is highly unlikely that the same
>  set of inputs will ever be repeated.
>  Will the network actually learn anything in this scenario and would it
>  show any improvement over time? If so, approximately how long would it
>  take before we can expect any learned behavior?

This is kind of a broad set of questions that apply to learning
anything, with any learning algorithm. It's understandable if the
inputs are never *exactly* the same. We never have the same exact
image processed by our retina, because of changes in lighting, POV,
etc. But the inputs should be sufficiently *similar* to learn the
proper associations.

If there are no discernible patterns or regularity in the input then
the input is basically noise, and of course your system won't learn
anything because there's nothing to learn.

What are you trying to teach the networks, exactly?

--Derek
